section.title: about scheduling
section.para: Linux administrators use the atat(1) to schedule one time jobs. Recurring jobs are better scheduled with croncron(8). The next two sections will discuss both tools.

section.title: at
section.para: Simple scheduling can be done with the atat(1) command. This screenshot shows the scheduling of the date command at 22:01 and the sleep command at 22:03.
section.screen: root@laika:~# at 22:01 at> date at> <EOT> job 1 at Wed Aug 1 22:01:00 2007 root@laika:~# at 22:03 at> sleep 10 at> <EOT> job 2 at Wed Aug 1 22:03:00 2007 root@laika:~#

para.emphasis: In real life you will hopefully be scheduling more useful commands ;-)

section.title: atq
section.para: It is easy to check when jobs are scheduled with the atqatq(1) or at -l commands.
section.screen: root@laika:~# atq 1 Wed Aug 1 22:01:00 2007 a root 2 Wed Aug 1 22:03:00 2007 a root root@laika:~# at -l 1 Wed Aug 1 22:01:00 2007 a root 2 Wed Aug 1 22:03:00 2007 a root root@laika:~#
section.para: The at command understands English words like tomorrow and teatime to schedule commands the next day and at four in the afternoon.
section.screen: root@laika:~# at 10:05 tomorrow at> sleep 100 at> <EOT> job 5 at Thu Aug 2 10:05:00 2007 root@laika:~# at teatime tomorrow at> tea at> <EOT> job 6 at Thu Aug 2 16:00:00 2007 root@laika:~# atq 6 Thu Aug 2 16:00:00 2007 a root 5 Thu Aug 2 10:05:00 2007 a root root@laika:~#

section.title: atrm
section.para: Jobs in the at queue can be removed with atrmatrm(1).
section.screen: root@laika:~# atq 6 Thu Aug 2 16:00:00 2007 a root 5 Thu Aug 2 10:05:00 2007 a root root@laika:~# atrm 5 root@laika:~# atq 6 Thu Aug 2 16:00:00 2007 a root root@laika:~#

section.title: at.allow and at.deny
section.para: You can also use the /etc/at.allow/etc/at.allow and /etc/at.deny/etc/at.deny files to manage who can schedule jobs with at.
The /etc/at.allow file can contain a list of users that are allowed to schedule at jobs. When /etc/at.allow does not exist, then everyone can use at unless their username is listed in /etc/at.deny.
If none of these files exist, then everyone can use at.
